identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New York

abstract.p: Larry Otis Graham, husband of Patricia Thomas-Graham, chief executive of CNBC.com, is 'the other Democrat from Chappaqua'; he is running to unseat Republican Repr Sue W Kelly (M)

block.p: The well-known spouse of a perhaps even better-known personality decides to run for public office from a New York City suburb. ''He's the other Democrat from Chappaqua,'' Patricia Thomas-Graham said last week of her husband, Larry Otis Graham, who is seeking to unseat the area's Republican Representative, Sue W. Kelly.

Ms. Thomas-Graham, chief executive of CNBC.com, was the first black woman to make partner at McKinsey & Company, and has written two strong-selling mysteries set at Ivy League schools. She promoted her husband's campaign -- ''We would all be extraordinarily lucky to be represented by such a person'' -- in accepting an award last week as the Financial Women's Association Private Sector Woman of the Year.

The well-known spouse of a perhaps even better-known personality decides to run for public office from a New York City suburb. ''He's the other Democrat from Chappaqua,'' Patricia Thomas-Graham said last week of her husband, Larry Otis Graham, who is seeking to unseat the area's Republican Representative, Sue W. Kelly.

Ms. Thomas-Graham, chief executive of CNBC.com, was the first black woman to make partner at McKinsey & Company, and has written two strong-selling mysteries set at Ivy League schools. She promoted her husband's campaign -- ''We would all be extraordinarily lucky to be represented by such a person'' -- in accepting an award last week as the Financial Women's Association Private Sector Woman of the Year.

Mary L. Shapiro, president of the National Association of Securities Dealers regulatory arm, was the Public Sector winner. Mr. Graham himself, as a writer on race relations with a favorably reviewed book to his credit, is still catching up with his wife in gaining the limelight.

PRIVATE SECTOR Correction: June 25, 2000, Sunday A brief report in the Private Sector column on June 4, about the campaign of Larry Otis Graham of Chappaqua, N.Y., for a Congressional seat, misstated the given name of his wife, the chief executive of CNBC.com She is Pamela Thomas-Graham, not Patricia.
